awd_titl_txt: Quantifying the roles of pollination and post-pollination barriers in flowering plant speciation: a case study of the diverse Neotropical genus Burmeistera (Campanulaceae)
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will investigate how flowering plants develop reproductive boundaries among species over time. Animal pollinators are critical to the reproduction and survival of most flowering plants, including many of our agricultural crops. Conventional wisdom holds that animal pollinators also have a primary role in driving the diversification of these species. However, this idea has rarely been tested in detail and at scale. Researchers will test this hypothesis using Burmeistera, a flowering plant genus whose 116 species depend on nectar-feeding bats for pollination. Burmeistera species place their pollen on different parts of the bats' heads, which may reduce the exchange of pollen and genes between species. They also have different degrees of genetic incompatibility with each other. These genetic barriers may reduce the fertilization success of cross-species pollinations or the survival of hybrid offspring. Researchers will evaluate which of these reproductive barriers contributes to each stage of the speciation process in Burmeistera. Undergraduate and graduate students, including those from underrepresented groups, will be involved in all aspects of the project and will be trained in field and laboratory techniques. The project will also support the professional development of a post-doctoral researcher. Researchers will communicate results to the public via educational displays at the Missouri Botanical Garden and bilingual field guides for Burmeistera species.

This project will discover how reproductive barriers evolve during angiosperm speciation using an integrated experimental and comparative approach. Researchers will construct a robust species-level phylogeny for Burmeistera (Campanulaceae, the bell-flower family) using DNA sequence data from whole plastomes and over 700 nuclear loci. They will then measure pre- and post-pollination reproductive barriers among pairs of species having different phylogenetic distances. Assessment will include cross-pollination trials by captive nectar-feeding bats as well as hand-crosses of species in cultivation. Researchers will compare these measures within the context of the phylogeny to test the hypothesis that post-pollination reproductive barriers evolve before others. They will also determine whether changes in the length of pollen-bearing and receiving organs of Burmeistera flowers are correlated with speciation events, which would be consistent with the hypothesis of pollinator-driven speciation. Project outcomes will include an exceptionally detailed exploration of angiosperm speciation processes, improved taxonomic circumscriptions within a poorly-studied Neotropical flowering plant group, and the creation of new genetic resources and herbarium collections. The project will strengthen international research collaborations among US, Ecuadorian and Colombian scientists.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to explore how new species of plants are formed. We focused on a group of plants (genus Burmeistera) in the bellflower family (Campanulaceae) that occurs in cloud forests in the mountains of Central and South America.  Previous work showed that they are pollinated primarily by nectar-feeding bats, and that they have appeared relatively recently and diversified into approximately 150 species in a short amount of time.  We began by working on the taxonomy of the group, determining which species names are valid and where these species are distributed.  This led to the description of 13 new species, and a publication detailing the 52 species known to occur in Ecuador. We are also finalizing work on an online guide, in Spanish and English, to all of the species in the genus.

We then extracted genetic material from leaf tissue of species across the genus, and sequenced hundreds of genes for each. With this information we constructed a tree of life that shows relationships of each species to each other. This suggests that the group originated in the western slopes of the Andes mountains of present-day Colombia, and distributed from there north through the mountains of Central America, east to Venezuela, and south to Peru. Species ranges are typically very small, and multiple species occur together within forests (typically 2-4, and up to 11).

So how did all of these species form? Species place their pollen on different parts of the heads of bats, which helps multiple species to exist within a forest without mixing pollen. However, bats still do pass pollen between species. Hundreds of experimental crosses between species show that such pollen transfer will not form seeds when species co-occur in the same forest, suggesting they have evolved ways to recognize foreign pollen. They will form hybrid seeds occasionally when pollen is carried between sites, and this tendency to form hybrid seeds is greater the more closely-related the species are. Genetic analyses show that many species share genes with many other species due to such hybridization events; this likely contributes to genetic variety and the ability to evolve quickly. By comparing the age that pairs of species split from each other to the strength of factors that could contribute to preventing the pairs from passing genes between them, we conclude that pollinators are less important in the formation of new species than are post-pollination factors, i.e. the ability to recognize foreign pollen and prevent it from fertilizing your seeds.

This project led to the publication of 11 scientific articles on our results. It supported research by two postdoctoral fellows and two graduate students, which led to one MS and one PhD thesis. The PI, graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows mentored a total of 6 US undergraduate students and 7 South American undergraduates (3 from Ecuador and 4 from Colombia) involved in labwork and fieldwork. Results were shared in 5 talks at scientific conferences and 4 talks to the general public, and were incorporated into classroom lectures.
